No model or unit can be targeted by more than one instance during the same Magic Phase. If The Sacrifice was performed, the Range of the spell is increased by +6".

rulebook-the_devouring_dark.title: The Devouring Dark
rulebook-the_devouring_dark.def: The target suffers a hit with Area Attack(2×2), Str 5, AP 2, and Magical Attacks.

rulebook-hand_of_glory.title: Hand of Glory
rulebook-hand_of_glory.def:
The target gains Aegis (6+) and Aegis (+1, max. 3+).



The Sacrifice may be performed for this spell.

rulebook-blood_curse.title: Blood Curse
rulebook-blood_curse.def:
The target suffers -1 Str and -1 AP.



The Sacrifice may be performed for this spell.

rulebook-pentagram_of_pain.title: Pentagram of Pain
rulebook-pentagram_of_pain.def:
The target suffers 3 hits, with Str 5, AP 2, and Magical Attacks. If one ore more unsaved wounds are caused with this spell, the Caster of the spell Recovers 1 HP.



The Sacrifice may be performed for this spell.

rulebook-the_grave_calls.title: The Grave Calls
rulebook-the_grave_calls.def:
The target suffers 8 hits, with Str 5, AP 2, and Magical Attacks.



The Sacrifice may be performed for this spell.

rulebook-umbral_majesty.title: Umbral Majesty
rulebook-umbral_majesty.def:
The target gains Dying Blow, and a single model part in the target gains Grind Attack(4, Str 5, AP 2, Magical Attacks).

Wherever possible, enemy models must allocate their Melee Attacks towards a Health Pool that is not the target.

rulebook-fireball.title: Fireball
rulebook-fireball.def:
The target suffers 2D3
hits with Str 4, AP 0, Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks
.

rulebook-flaming_swords.title: Flaming Swords
rulebook-flaming_swords.def: The target gains +1 to wound, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magical_attacks">Magical Attacks</nuxt-link> (Melee & Shooting), <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/flaming_attacks">Flaming Attacks</nuxt-link> (Melee & Shooting).

rulebook-dragons_roar.title: Dragon's Roar
rulebook-dragons_roar.def:
A single model part in the target gains Breath Attack(Str 4, AP 0, Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks), and

Grind Attack(2D6, Str 4, AP 0, Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks).

rulebook-pyroclastic_flow.title: Pyroclastic Flow
rulebook-pyroclastic_flow.def:
The target suffers 5D3
hits with Str 4, AP 0, Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks
.

rulebook-pillars_of_fire.title: Pillars of Fire
rulebook-pillars_of_fire.def: Standard Melee Attacks from Rank-and-File models in the target hit automatically, have their Str always set to 4, AP always set to 0, and gain Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks.

rulebook-cage_of_embers.title: Cage of Embers
rulebook-cage_of_embers.def:
Immediately when the spell is cast, and whenever the target moves, it suffers 2D3
hits with Str 4, AP 0, Flaming Attacks, Magical Attacks
. Afterwards, it gains Weakness(Flaming Attacks).

rulebook-predators_instinct.title: Predator's Instinct
rulebook-predators_instinct.def:
The target gains +2" Cha and Resistance(Ranged Attacks).



No model or unit can be affected by more than one instance of this spell simultaneously.

rulebook-awaken_the_beast.title: Awaken the Beast
rulebook-awaken_the_beast.def: The target gains +1 Str and +1 AP.

rulebook-swarm_of_insects.title: Swarm of Insects
rulebook-swarm_of_insects.def:
Immediately when the spell is cast, the target suffers 5D6 hits with AP 0 and Magical Attacks. These hits always wound on 6+.

In addition, it suffers -1 to hit with Shooting Attacks.

rulebook-savage_fury.title: Savage Fury
rulebook-savage_fury.def: The target gains <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fury">Fury</nuxt-link>, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fearless">Fearless</nuxt-link>, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/unruly">Unruly</nuxt-link>, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/frenzy">Frenzy</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-totemic_summon.title: Totemic Summon
rulebook-totemic_summon.def: Summon a Totemic Beast (profile below), that is immediately placed on the Battlefield using the rules for Ambush(Board Edge).

rulebook-wild_shape.title: Wild Shape
rulebook-wild_shape.def: The target's Height is increased by +1, to a maximum of 5, and it gains +1 Res and Stomp Attack(1). If it already had Stomp Attack, the number of hits caused by its Stomp Attack is increased by +1.

rulebook-divine_intervention.title: Divine Intervention
rulebook-divine_intervention.def:
When resolving the effects of a Thaumaturgy spell, roll a D6:


  • On a ‘5’ or ‘6’: Apply the Blessing effects, marked with a .

  • On a ‘1’: Apply the Admonition effects, marked with a .

rulebook-smite_the_unbeliever.title: Smite the Unbeliever
rulebook-smite_the_unbeliever.def:
The target suffers D6 hits with Str 5, AP 2, and Magical Attacks.


  • : These hits are instead resolved with Str 7.

  • : These hits are instead resolved with Str 3.

rulebook-light_of_faith.title: Light of Faith
rulebook-light_of_faith.def:
The target immediately suffers 2D6 hits with Str 2, AP 0, Magical Attacks, and Divine Attacks.


  • : The target gains Minimise Flee rolls.

  • : The target gains Maximised Flee rolls.

rulebook-weight_of_judgement.title: Weight of Judgement
rulebook-weight_of_judgement.def:
The target suffers -10 Agi, to a minimum of 1.


  • : Enemy* units in the same combat as the target suffer -10 Agi, to a minimum of 1.

  • : Friendly* units in the same combat as the target suffer -10 Agi, to a minimum of 1.


*From the perspective of the Caster.

At the time of casting the spell.

rulebook-holy_affliction.title: Holy Affliction
rulebook-holy_affliction.def:
The target suffers -1 to wound.


  • : The target suffers -1 AP.

  • : The target gains +1 AP.

rulebook-rain_of_fire.title: Rain of Fire
rulebook-rain_of_fire.def:
The target suffers D3+1 hits, and all units within 3" of the target suffer 1 hit. These hits are resolved with Str 9, AP 4, Magical Attacks, Flaming Attacks.


  • : Increase the number of hits each unit suffers from this Spell by 1.

  • : Decrease the number of hits each unit suffers from this Spell by 1.

rulebook-wrath_of_god.title: Wrath of God
rulebook-wrath_of_god.def:
Place a marker on the target point. Instead of rolling for Divine Intervention when the spell is cast, do it at the start of each subsequent Magic Phase.


  • : Each unit within 2D6" from the center of the marker suffers 2D6 with Str 5, AP 2, and Magical Attacks. Then remove the marker.

  • : The opponent may move the marker in any direction up to 3".

rulebook-evil_eye.title: Evil Eye
rulebook-evil_eye.def:
The target suffers -1 Cou and loses Devastating Charge and/or First Strike (if it has them). If the target rolls for the number of Impact Hits, this roll is Minimised.



No model or unit can be affected by more than one instance of this spell simultaneously.

rulebook-soured_luck.title: Soured Luck
rulebook-soured_luck.def: Melee Attacks against the target are set to hit on 2+.

rulebook-illusory_paths.title: Illusory Paths
rulebook-illusory_paths.def:
Choose which effect to apply when casting the spell:


  • The target gains Random Movement(2D6").

  • The target gains Random Movement(3D6").

rulebook-cauldrons_curse.title: Cauldron's Curse
rulebook-cauldrons_curse.def: The target gains Weakness(Ranged Attacks).

rulebook-mists_of_invisibility.title: Mists of Invisibility
rulebook-mists_of_invisibility.def:
Mark the ground under the center of the target. The target gains Ambush(within 12" of the marked point). Then remove the target from the Battlefield. It automatically passes the roll to return to the Battlefield in your next Player Turn.


*Cannot target Shaken units

rulebook-clouded_sight.title: Clouded Sight
rulebook-clouded_sight.def: The target cannot draw <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/line_of_sight">Line of Sight</nuxt-link> to a target more than 12" from it.

rulebook-infantry.title: Infantry
rulebook-infantry.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/infantry">Infantry</nuxt-link> does not grant additional <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> Rules

rulebook-cavalry.title: Cavalry
rulebook-cavalry.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> has Cannot be Stomped, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/swiftstride">Swiftstride</nuxt-link> and

rulebook-construct.title: Construct
rulebook-construct.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> cannot use  and has Chariot

rulebook-ambush.title: Ambush
rulebook-ambush.def:
Units with Ambush may choose to not be deployed normally, by simply not placing it on the Battlefield during Deployment. If so, the unit will arrive at the Battlefield at a later point during the game. From your Player Turn 2 and onwards, roll a D6 for all Ambushing unit at the start of the Movement Phase (Before Random Movement). All units that rolled 3+ will enter the Battlefield. During your Player Turn 5 and 6, this roll is always considered to have rolled a 3+.

When a unit arrives, pick a point on the Battlefield as specified by (X) . If the roll is failed, or the unit could not enter for other reasons, roll again to see if it arrives in the next friendly Player Turn. If no suitable spot is available where the unit can be placed on the Battlefield, the unit cannot enter this turn.

  • Place the unit with at least three of it's four corners within 6" from the chosen point. There must be no other units or Impassable Terrain directly between any point on the unit’s Boundary and the chosen point. See the figure below for examples.

  • Ambushing units count as having performed an Advance Move when they arrive, and cannot perform Move Manoeuvres in the same Phase (including Random Movement; it may Magic Move).


  • If an Ambushing unit does not enter the Battlefield by the end of the game, it is considered Destroyed.

  • An Attachable Model with Ambush can arrive at the Battlefield together with an Ambushing unit it can join, following the usual restrictions. It needs to be in Ambush and have the same (X). Declare this before rolling to see if the unit arrives, and make a single dice roll for the Combined Unit.If the Combined Unit did not enter the battlefield, the Attached Model can declare that it joins a different unit or no unit in the next friendly Player Turn.

  • A unit that Ambushes in Game Turn 6 loses Scoring.

Deploying Ambushing units.In these examples, the unit has Ambush(Table Edge). The unit with the yellow check mark is placed in a legal position, while the two units with red crosses are not. The left one because there is an Impassable Terrain Feature between its unit Boundary and the chosen point, and the right one because parts of the unit are more than 6" away from the chosen point.

rulebook-attached.title: Attached
rulebook-attached.def: This model must be deployed inside a unit with at least one Rank-and-File model, and it cannot voluntarily leave its unit.

rulebook-bodyguard.title: Bodyguard
rulebook-bodyguard.def: While a Character, that fulfils the criteria defined in brackets (X), is joined to a unit containing Bodyguard, that Character gains Stubborn, and if the unit it is joined to has at least one Proper Rank, the unit is considered Steady and Solid for the purposes of Break Tests.

rulebook-captain.title: Captain
rulebook-captain.def:
A unit containing Captain gains the following additions rules.


  • If the unit has a Standard Bearer, it is considered to be within range of its Battle Standard Bearer’s* Rally Around the Flag.

  • If the unit has a Musician, it is considered to be within range of its General’s* Commanding Presence.

A unit can only contain a single Attachable Model with Captain.
*Provided such models are on the Battlefield at all.

rulebook-channel.title: Channel
rulebook-channel.def: During <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/siphon_the_veil">Siphon the Veil</nuxt-link>, each of the Active Player’s <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">models</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/channel">Channel</nuxt-link> adds X Magic <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/dice">Dice</nuxt-link> to their owner’s Magic <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/dice">Dice</nuxt-link> pool.

rulebook-commanding_presence.title: Commanding Presence
rulebook-commanding_presence.def:
If any friendly unit is within 12" of the model:


  • Its Courage is set to the Courage of the model with Commanding Presence, unless its original value is higher.


Apply any modifiers to the model’s Courage first, then set the recipient model’s Courage to that value. No single source of modifiers are applied more than once.


  • It gains Disciplined, if the model with Commanding Presence has it.

If the model with Commanding Presence is Shaken, this rule cannot be used.
If rules, properties or unit names are mentioned in brackets following this rule (X), it means that only units possessing these qualities can benefit from the model’s Commanding Presence.

rulebook-deafening_clamour.title: Deafening Clamour
rulebook-deafening_clamour.def: Enemy units within 12" cannot use Musician.

rulebook-dying_blow.title: Dying Blow
rulebook-dying_blow.def: When a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/dying_blow">Dying Blow</nuxt-link> is about to be <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/removed">removed</nuxt-link> during any Agility Step of a Round of Combat it is fighting, remove it instead as a casualty at the end of Agility Step 0.

rulebook-engineer.title: Engineer
rulebook-engineer.def:
Once during each Shooting Phase, a non-Shaken and Unengaged model with Engineer can select a friendly model with X in a unit within 6" of it.

The chosen model gains +1 to hit with Shooting Attacks, to a maximum of 3+. The usage of this must be declared before rolling to hit.

rulebook-exclusive.title: Exclusive
rulebook-exclusive.def:
This rule limits which Attachable Model is allowed to join what unit.


  • Attachable Models with Exclusive(X) can only join units containing X.

  • Non-Attachable Models with Exclusive(X) can only be joined by Attachable Models.

  • Models with Exclusive without brackets cannot join units or be joined by other models at all.

  • If a unit has multiple instances of Exclusive, all criteria must be fullfilled.

Ex: a Goblin Chieftain with Exclusive (Goblin, Troll) and Exclusive would not be able to join any units.

If it instead had Exclusive (Goblin, Troll) and Exclusive (Goblin, Orc) it would only be able to join goblins.

The specific criteria for X can include but is not limited to
: unit names, Model Rules, or upgrades.

If a model has both Exclusive and Attached, apply all requirements from both rules. (Remember that a model that cannot be deployed is considered a casualty.)

rulebook-fearless.title: Fearless
rulebook-fearless.def: A unit containing Fearless automatically passes Panic Tests, cannot choose Flee! as a Charge Reaction unless it’s already Shaken, or the entire unit has Feigned Flight, and ignores the effects of Horror.

rulebook-feigned_flight.title: Feigned Flight
rulebook-feigned_flight.def:
At the end of a Round ofCombat, if a unit with Feigned Flight is still Engaged with an enemy unit, before rolling any Break Tests, any unit with Feigned Flight may choose to voluntarily break from the Combat. If so, the unit is considered to have failed a Break Test. If the unit was on the winning side of the combat, the enemy cannot Pursue.

In addition, any Rally Tests taken by units with Feigned Flight after voluntarily becoming Shaken (either due to Charge Reaction Flee! or disengaging from combat), are automatically passed. This cannot be used if the unit has performed another Flee move before rolling the Rally Test.

Models with Fearless and Feigned Flight are not prevented from choosing Charge Reaction Flee! due to Fearless.

Remember that a voluntary Flee Move does not cause a Panic Test in friendly units that the Fleeing unit moves through.

rulebook-fly.title: Fly
rulebook-fly.def:
Units with Fly ignore: Terrain Features, Open Terrain and other units during Move Manoeuvres and Charge Moves. The unit must still follow the Unit Spacing rule at the end of its moves. Terrain Features and Open Terrain from which the model starts or ends its move still affect it.\
During a Charge Move, the charged unit is not ignored, and there must be room for the unit’s Front Facing to be placed in contact with the charged unit before the Align Move.

rulebook-frenzy.title: Frenzy
rulebook-frenzy.def: Units containing Frenzy must always choose to Pursue (including Overrun), when able to.

rulebook-ghost_step.title: Ghost Step
rulebook-ghost_step.def:
A unit with Ghost Step ignores Terrain Features and Open Terrain when moving. The unit must however follow the Unit Spacing rule at the end of its move.

If the unit ends a move inside Impassable Terrain, backtrack the move to the unit’s last legal position, unless as part of a Flee Move, in which case the standard Flee Moves rules apply.

When a model with Ghost Step is part of a unit where some models do not have Ghost Step, and this unit is about to roll Dangerous Terrain Tests, consider the Terrain Feature or Open Terrain to have the criteria "model without Ghost Step" (i.e. ignore models with Ghost Step when calculating number of tests and allocating attacks).

rulebook-afflict.title: Afflict
rulebook-afflict.def:
Units in contact with one or more enemy models with Afflict(X), suffer the effects given by X.
A unit can only be affected by one instance of each Afflict(X), provided that the X in brackets is identical. If the brackets from two instances of Afflict are not identical, i.e. different X, then they are considered different rules and the effects from both are applied.

rulebook-hidden.title: Hidden
rulebook-hidden.def:
The model is not deployed as normal. Instead, at the start of any Player Turn, the owner can choose a friendly unit containing Rank-and-File models, which satisfy the following:


  • The model with Hidden could normally have joined the unit.

  • The model with Hidden has an identical Base Size and Height as the Rank-and-File models in the unit.

  • The unit is not Shaken, is not a Summoned unit, but it can be Engaged in Combat.

After choosing an eligible unit, follow these steps:


  • Remove a Rank-and-File model, with the same base size as the model with Hidden, from the front rank of the chosen unit as a casualty.

  • Deploy the model with Hidden where the removed model was positioned.

rulebook-insignificant.title: Insignificant
rulebook-insignificant.def: Units with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/insignificant">Insignificant</nuxt-link> do not cause <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/panic_tests">Panic Tests</nuxt-link> on units not containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/insignificant">Insignificant</nuxt-link> when making <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/flee_move">Flee Moves</nuxt-link> through them.

rulebook-light_troops.title: Light Troops
rulebook-light_troops.def:
A unit with Light Troops can perform Reform Move Manoeuvres at twice its Mobility. (instead of the normal half Mobility).


  • If its centre moves further than its Mobility, the move is considered a March Move for the purpose of rules triggering due to Marching. E.g. Dangerous Terrain test, and if Undead being restricted from performing a March Move.\
For the purpose of shooting, this is still considered a Reform Move.\
note that this rule has no effect on other Move Manoeuvres, including March Moves

  • If the Reform Move is started within 3" of a non-Shaken enemy unit with at least one Proper Rank; the Reform Move is instead limited to its Mobility.

Units containing Light Troops are always considered to have zero Proper Ranks. Ignore Attachable Models with Light Troops joined to a unit for this, unless the unit consists of only Attachable Models.

rulebook-magic_resistance.title: Magic Resistance
rulebook-magic_resistance.def: When an enemy <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> casts a spell that targets a unit containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magic_resistance">Magic Resistance</nuxt-link>, the Casting Roll of the spell is decreased by X, where X is the highest <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magic_resistance">Magic Resistance</nuxt-link> value in the unit.

rulebook-meetingofminds.title: Meeting of Minds
rulebook-meetingofminds.def: The model gains Scent of Blood and treats all friendly models with Beast as Insignificant.

rulebook-protean_magic.title: Protean Magic
rulebook-protean_magic.def: The model knows X Learned Spells and is a Wizard. It does not choose a Path of Magic, instead it can select the Apprentice Spell (#1) from all Paths available to it. See Battle Preparation chapter for details.

rulebook-rally_around_the_flag.title: Rally Around the Flag
rulebook-rally_around_the_flag.def: Models within 12" of a friendly non-Shaken model with Rally Around the Flag must reroll failed Courage Tests.

rulebook-random_movement.title: Random Movement
rulebook-random_movement.def:
Units with Random Movement do not follow normal rules for Charging, Move Manoeuvres, Pursue Moves or Flee Moves. Instead, apply the following:


  • During the Charge Phase, the model cannot Declare any Charges.

  • At any time the model would perform a Move Manoeuvre, the unit performs a Pursue Move (see Melee chapter) with the following exceptions:

  • It must move in the Movement Phase if allowed to do so, and it must do so before any units without Random Movement have performed their Move Manoeuvres.

  • It moves the distance stated in brackets (X).

  • It can choose which direction it will move in. The owning player must choose which direction before rolling the Pursuit Distance.

  • It does not take Dangerous Terrain Tests unless Charging.

  • It treats the Board Edge as Impassable Terrain.

  • It counts as an Advance Move for the purpose of Moving and Shooting.




  • Note that this means a model with Random Movement cannot perform Magical Moves or use Vanguard.





  • The model’s Pursue and Flee moves use the distance stated in brackets (X), instead of the normal distance.

Whenever a rule requires the Mobility or Charge Speed of the model, use the potential maximum value of X.

rulebook-resolute.title: Resolute
rulebook-resolute.def: A unit containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/resolute">Resolute</nuxt-link>, that has at least one Proper Rank is considered to have X additional Proper Ranks, when Engaged .

rulebook-scout.title: Scout
rulebook-scout.def:
Units with Scout are not required to be deployed inside its Deployment Zone. They may be deployed anywhere on the Battlefield that is at least 12" away from the opponent’s deployment Zone.

A unit that starts the game outside their own Deployment Zone cannot declare a Charge in the first Player Turn of the first Game Turn.

rulebook-skirmisher.title: Skirmisher
rulebook-skirmisher.def:
Units containing Skirmisher adopt a unique formation, called a skirmish formation . Instead of being in contact with each other, these models are placed 12.5mm apart (roughly half an inch, see the figure below). These gaps between the models are considered part of the unit for Cover and Line of Sight purposes, and have the same Height as the unit. Other than this gap between models, units with Skirmisher follow the normal rules for forming units and therefore have a Front, two Flanks, and a Rear Facing, can perform Supporting Attacks, and so on.

Units in Skirmish formation can only be joined by Attachable Models that have the same Height as the unit. Unless an Attachable Model has the exact same base size as all Rank-and-File models in the unit, it is considered Mismatched for the purpose of placement within the unit.

The unit ceases to be in Skirmish formation when all models with Skirmisher have been removed. When this happens, contract their skirmish formation into a normal formation when returning the unit into a legal formation, without moving the centre of the first rank. Nudge any unit as normal to maintain contact if Engaged in Combat.

See figure figure/skirmisher for an illustration of this rule.

Skirmish formation.An example of a unit in Skirmish formation with a joined Mismatching Character. All models are 12.5 mm away from each other.\
The same unit Engaged in Combat. Only darkened models may attack. Models with a dashed frame can attack a Character (either C1 or C2). Models with a lighter shade cannot attack at all.

rulebook-stand_behind.title: Stand Behind
rulebook-stand_behind.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attachable_models">Attachable Models</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/stand_behind">Stand Behind</nuxt-link> are not required to have their Front Facing as far forward as possible within their unit. Essentially this means that the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> can be positioned anywhere within its unit. This rule cannot be used while the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> has a mismatching base to its unit.

rulebook-strider.title: Strider
rulebook-strider.def:
Models with Strider may (must if Shaken) ignore rules associated with Terrain Features, with the following exceptions:


  • Any rule affecting Line of Sight or Cover.

  • Any rule associated with Weakness.

  • Impassable (see Impassable Terrain).

Occasionally, Strider is associated with a specific type of Terrain, which would be indicated in brackets (X). In such cases, Strider only affects this particular Terrain Feature.

When a model with Strider is part of a unit where some models do not have Strider, and this unit is about to roll Dangerous Terrain Tests, consider the Terrain Feature to have the criteria "model without Strider" (i.e. ignore models with Strider when calculating number of tests and allocating attacks).

rulebook-stubborn.title: Stubborn
rulebook-stubborn.def:
When a unit containing Stubborn loses a Round of Combat, the modifier to the Courage from the Combat Score difference is halved, rounding fractions up (i.e. towards a larger modifier). Note that if the unit is also Steady, the modifier is first set to no smaller than 2 following the Steady rules, and then halved, rounding up, to 1.

If the unit is Unstable, the Health Point losses due to Unstable are halved, rounding fractions up (i.e. towards more Health Point losses).

rulebook-supernal.title: Supernal
rulebook-supernal.def:
When a unit with Supernal fails a Break Test, instead of being Broken and subsequently Shaken, it suffers a number of Health Point losses equal to the amount by which the combat was lost, with no saves of any kind allowed.

These Health Point losses are first allocated towards Rank-and-File models, and once enough Health Points losses are suffered to remove all Rank-and-File models, remaining Health Point losses are allocated by the owner towards Attachable Models, as evenly as possible.

Attachable Models with Supernal can only join units containing Supernal, and units containing Supernal can only be joined by Attachable Models with Supernal.

rulebook-swiftstride.title: Swiftstride
rulebook-swiftstride.def: Rolls for range on Charge Range, Flee Distance and Pursue Distance by units with Swiftstride gain Maximised.

rulebook-terror.title: Terror
rulebook-terror.def: When a unit containing Terror declares a Charge in the Charge Phase, the target must take a Panic Test. If the test is failed, the unit must choose Flee! as its Charge Reaction if allowed to do so (e.g. not already Engaged in Combat). Note that this Flee Move is not considered voluntary, and thus friendly units that may be required to take a Panic Test when moving through them. Units containing Terror are immune to the effects of Terror.

rulebook-undead.title: Undead
rulebook-undead.def:
Units containing Undead cannot perform March Moves unless the unit may benifit from a friendly model’s Commanding Presence.

Models with Undead have an additional characteristic called Resurrect (Rsr) on their statline. Whenever a Health Pool with a Resurrect value is about to Raise or Recover a Health Point, it instead Raises or Recovers an amount of Health Points equal to its Resurrect value.

rulebook-unruly.title: Unruly
rulebook-unruly.def: Command Tests taken by a unit containing Unruly gain Minimised.

rulebook-unstable.title: Unstable
rulebook-unstable.def:
When a unit with Unstable would take a Break Test, instead it suffers a number of Health Point losses equal to the amount by which the combat was lost, with no saves of any kind allowed.

These Health Point losses are first allocated towards Rank-and-File models, and once enough Health Points losses are suffered to remove all Rank-and-File models, remaining Health Point losses are allocated by the owner towards Attachable Models, as evenly as possible.

The Health Point losses can be reduced in the following ways:


  • Remember that if the unit has Stubborn, the Health Point losses are halved, rounding fractions up.

  • If the unit is affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by 1.

  • If the unit is Steady while affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by an additional 1.

  • If the unit is Solid while affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by an additional 1.

I.e. a unit that is affected by Rally Around the Flag while being Steady and Solid reduces the Health Point losses by a total of 3.

Attachable Models with Unstable can only join units containing Unstable, and units containing Unstable can only be joined by Attachable Models with Unstable.

rulebook-vanguard.title: Vanguard
rulebook-vanguard.def:
After deployment, units with Vanguard may perform a pre-game Move Manoeuvre (Reform, Advance, or March Move), with the following exceptions:


  • If an X is given, the unit’s Mobility is set to always X" during this move.

  • No model can move further than 12" during this move, regardless of its Mobility.

  • It cannot move within 6" of an enemy unit.

  • Attachable Models cannot leave a unit as part of this move.

If both players have units with Vanguard, they alternate moving units one by one, starting with the unit that the Defender chose for Defender's Advantage.

A unit that starts the game outside its own Deployment Zone cannot declare a Charge in the first Player Turn of the first Game Turn.

rulebook-warplatform.title: WarPlatform
rulebook-warplatform.def:
The model follows the rules for Attachable Models, with the following exceptions:


  • If can never perform Make Way moves, not even if it is also a Character.

  • For the purpose of allocating Ranged Attacks onto a unit with a WarPlatform joined to it, the model with WarPlatform is considered to be the same Height as the other Rank-and-File models in the same unit. If there are no other Rank-and-File models in the unit, ignore this rule.

  • Only a single model with WarPlatform can be joined to the same unit.

When the model is joined to a unit, its Mobility and Charge Speed is set to that of its unit, applying the following restrictions:


  • If there are no Rank-and-File models from the unit in contact with the WarPlatform’s flank Facings (right and left side), the model must use its own Mobility and Charge Speed instead Meaning that, if slower than the unit, the unit’s Mobility and Charge Speed are set to those of the WarPlatform.

  • The WarPlatform cannot use the unit’s Mobility and Charge Speed values when leaving the unit, including charging out of it. Instead, it uses its own Mobility and Charge Speed.

rulebook-wizard_apprentice.title: Wizard Apprentice
rulebook-wizard_apprentice.def: The model becomes a Wizard, knows 1 Learned Spell, which is the Apprentice Spell (#1) of the Path it has chosen. It may do certain spell changes during Pre-game Selections. See Battle Preparation chapter for details.

rulebook-wizard_adept.title: Wizard Adept
rulebook-wizard_adept.def: The model becomes a Wizard, gains Channel (1), and knows 3 Learned Spells; chosen from the Apprentice Spell and the Adept Spells (#1 - #4) of the Path it has chosen. It may do certain spell changes during Pre-game Selections. See Battle Preparation chapter for details.

rulebook-wizard_master.title: Wizard Master
rulebook-wizard_master.def: The model becomes a Wizard, gains Channel (2) and knows 5 Learned Spells; chosen from the Apprentice Spell, the Adept, and Master Spells (#1 - #6) of the Path it has chosen. It may do certain spell changes during Pre-game Selections. See Battle Preparation chapter for details.

rulebook-wizard_conclave.title: Wizard Conclave
rulebook-wizard_conclave.def:
The unit knows X Learned Spells, chosen from the list of available spells in its unit entry, is a Wizard and if X is 2 or more it also gains Channel (1). The unit may only do a Hereditary Swap if it could have picked the Hereditary Spell during 1.B.a Spell Selections. It is always eligible for a Universal Swap. See Battle Preparation chapter for details.

Despite the whole unit knowing spells only one model is a Caster. Just before choosing targets for a spell, select one Rank-and-File model as the Caster for this spell.
When a Wizard Conclave suffers a Miscast, treat the entire unit as the Caster.

rulebook-mindless.title: Mindless
rulebook-mindless.def: A unit with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/mindless">Mindless</nuxt-link> automatically passes its <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command tests</nuxt-link> for Combat Reforming, and automatically fails its <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command Tests</nuxt-link> for Redirecting Charges.

rulebook-emplacement.title: Emplacement
rulebook-emplacement.def:
Units with Emplacement cannot Declare Charges, perform March Moves or Pursue Moves (including Random Movement), or choose the Flee! Charge Reaction. If a unit with Emplacement is about to perform a Flee Move, it is instead removed as a Casualty. The model cannot shoot in the same Player Turn that it performed a Move Manoeuvre.
Units with Emplacement can draw Line of Sight in any direction from any points on their base (i.e. they are not limited by their Front Facing or Front Arc).

rulebook-not_a_hero.title: Not a Hero
rulebook-not_a_hero.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> can neither Issue nor Accept Duels.

rulebook-aegis.title: Aegis
rulebook-aegis.def:
Aegis is a Special Save, with a value indicated in brackets (X). If X is given as a modifier and with a maximum value (e.g. +2), the model gains this as a modifier to all its Aegis Special Save rolls, which cannot be increased to rolls better than 3+. If the model doesn’t have Aegis, it instead gains a Aegis (7 X+). For example, a model without Aegis that gains Aegis (+2) will gain Aegis (5+).

Note that Aegis Saves cannot be taken against attacks with the Divine Attacks Attack Attribute.

rulebook-distracting.title: Distracting
rulebook-distracting.def:
Melee Attacks allocated against a Health Pool with Distracting suffer X to hit, up to at worst 5+.

If a Max. Y apply this following the normal rules for limits defined in the Reference Handbook .

rulebook-regeneration.title: Regeneration
rulebook-regeneration.def:
Regeneration is a Special Save, with a value indicated in brackets (X).

If X is given as a modifier and with a maximum value (e.g. +2), the model gains this as a modifier to all its Regeneration Special Save rolls, which cannot be increased to rolls better than 3+. If the model doesn’t have Regeneration, it instead gains a Regeneration (7 X+). For example, a model without Regeneration that gains Regeneration (+2) will gain Regeneration (5+).
Regeneration Saves cannot be taken against attacks with Flaming Attacks, nor against attacks with Lethal Strike that roll a natural ‘6’ to wound.

rulebook-hard_target.title: Hard Target
rulebook-hard_target.def: Shooting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against a Health Pool with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hard_target">Hard Target</nuxt-link> suffer X to hit.

rulebook-immune.title: Immune
rulebook-immune.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> with the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attack_attributes">Attack Attributes</nuxt-link> or <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/properties">Properties</nuxt-link> stated in brackets (X) allocated towards the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/immune">Immune</nuxt-link> (X) lose these <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attack_attributes">Attack Attributes</nuxt-link> or <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/properties">Properties</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-parry.title: Parry
rulebook-parry.def:
The Defensive Skill of a model with Parry is always set to at least the Offensive Skill of the attacker.
Remember that since Parry provides a modifier to a Defensive Characteristic, this is not applicable to a Character with a mount with its own Defensive Skill.

rulebook-resistance.title: Resistance
rulebook-resistance.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model’s</nuxt-link> Health Pool must reroll successful <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-weakness.title: Weakness
rulebook-weakness.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model’s</nuxt-link> Health Pool must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-melee_weapons.title: Melee Weapons
rulebook-melee_weapons.def:
1whiteblack!5
5pt

Name & Characteristics Modifiers & Model Rules
Innate Weapons \All model parts with Mount, Beast, or Construct come equipped with Innate Weapons as their default equipment and cannot lose them. & -- & When Choosing Equipment and Abilities, a model part can only choose Innate Weapons if it has no other options.
Hand Weapon \All model parts without Innate Weapons come equipped with a Hand Weapon as their default equipment and cannot lose it. & -- & Models using a Hand Weapon alongside a Shield gain Parry.

When Choosing Equipment and Abilities, a model part can only choose a Hand Weapon if it has no other options, or is Weapon Master. E.g. a model Part equipped with just a Hand Weapon and Innate Weapons, must use its Hand Weapon.
Great Weapon & +2 Str, +2 AP, always Agi* & Two-Handed *Always strike at Agility Step 0, regardless of the wielder’s Agility.
Halberd & +1 Str, +1 AP & Two-Handed.
Lance \Only models with Mount or Centauroid can use Lances. & Devastating Charge(+2 Str, +2 AP, +1 Agi) & --
Light Lance \Only models with Mount or Centauroid can use Light Lances. & Devastating Charge(+1 Str, +1 AP) & --
Paired Weapons & +1 Att, +1 Off & Two-Handed. Attacks made with Paired Weapons ignore Parry.
Spear \Models with Mount or Centauroid cannot use Spears. & \+1 Agi, +1 AP, +1 additional AP against Mount & Fight in Extra Rank,

Melee Combat Weapons

rulebook-great_weapon.title: Great Weapon
rulebook-great_weapon.def:
+2 Str, +2 AP, always Agi*, Two-Handed

*Always strike at Agility Step 0, regardless of the wielder’s Agility.

rulebook-hand_weapon.title: Hand Weapon
rulebook-hand_weapon.def: All models come equipped with a Hand Weapon as their default equipment and cannot lose it. & -- & Models using a Hand Weapon alongside a Shield gain Parry. A model equipped with another Melee Weapon must use this, and cannot use its Hand Weapon.

rulebook-lance.title: Lance
rulebook-lance.def: Models on foot cannot use Lances. Devastating Charge(+2 Str, +2 AP, +1 Agi)

rulebook-light_lance.title: Light Lance
rulebook-light_lance.def: Models on foot cannot use Light Lances. Devastating Charge(+1 Str, +1 AP)

rulebook-paired_weapons.title: Paired Weapons
rulebook-paired_weapons.def: +1 Att, +1 Off, Two-Handed. Attacks made with Paired Weapons ignore Parry

rulebook-spear.title: Spear
rulebook-spear.def: Mounted models cannot use Spears. +1 Agi, Fight in Extra Rank, +3 AP against Swiftstride*. *AP Bonus Cannot be used when Charging.

rulebook-shooting_weapons.title: Shooting Weapons
rulebook-shooting_weapons.def:
1whiteblack!5
5pt

Name & Range & Shots & Str & AP & Model Rules
Bow & 24" & 1 - 3 - 0 - Shoot in Extra Rank.
Crossbow & 30" & 1 - 4 - 1 - Unwieldy (1).
Handgun & 24" & 1 - 4 - 2 - Unwieldy (1).
Longbow & 30" & 1 - 3 - 0 - Shoot in Extra Rank.
Pistol & 12" & 1 - 4 - 2 - Quick to Fire, Stand and Shoot.
Throwing Weapons & 8" & 2 - as user & as user & Accurate, Quick to Fire, Stand and Shoot.
Breath Attack (X) & 8" & 2D6 - X & X & One use only. March and Shoot. Hits automatically (no to-hit roll required). The Strength, Armour Penetration, and additional Attack Attributes are defined in brackets (X).



Shooting Weapons

rulebook-pistol.title: Pistol
rulebook-pistol.def: Range 12", Shots 1, Str 4, AP 2, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/quick_to_fire">Quick to Fire</nuxt-link>

rulebook-throwing_weapons.title: Throwing Weapons
rulebook-throwing_weapons.def: Range 8", Shots 2, Str as user, AP as user, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/accurate">Accurate</nuxt-link>, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/quick_to_fire">Quick to Fire</nuxt-link>

rulebook-stand_and_shoot.title: Stand and Shoot
rulebook-stand_and_shoot.def:
The model may perform an out of sequence Shooting Attack when an enemy unit has successfully performed a Charge Move into contact with the model’s unit, if the following conditions are met:


  • The model’s unit is not Engaged in Combat with any other units. Note that this means during a Combined Charge only the first Charging Unit moved can be targeted; except if the Charging Unit is removed at the end of its move. As long as the Charging Unit is removed at the end of its move, there is no limit on the amount of times a unit may use Stand and Shoot.


  • The enemy unit Charges the model in its unit’s Front Facing.

  • The enemy unit started the Charge further away than its Charge Speed, using the lowest Charge Speed in the unit.



  • The Charge was not done as part of a Pursue Move.

This is a Shooting Attack that does not require Line of Sight, can be done even if the enemy unit is not in the Shooter's Front Arc, and is always resolved against the target unit's Front Facing.

rulebook-artillery.title: Artillery
rulebook-artillery.def:
The attack ignores to-hit modifiers from Cover. It also gains +1 to-hit when shooting at units that fulfill any of the following criteria based on the target's Height:

  • Height 0-2; at least 3 ranks.

  • Height 3-4; at least 2 ranks.

  • Height 5; always.

rulebook-advantaged_position.title: Advantaged Position
rulebook-advantaged_position.def: The attack gain +1 to wound, to a maximum of 3+.

rulebook-accurate.title: Accurate
rulebook-accurate.def: The attack does not suffer the 1 to-hit modifier for shooting at Long Range.

rulebook-area_attack.title: Area Attack
rulebook-area_attack.def:
Before making a Shooting Attack with Area Attack, determine the attack's Target Facing hits using the same rules as for Cover.

If the attack hits in the Front or Rear: Select up to Y different ranks of the target. If the attack hits in the Flank: Select up to Y different files of the target. For each rank or file chosen this way, the unit takes X hits, up to a maximum equal to the number of models in that rank or file. An Area Attack can not cause more hits than the total models in the unit, and no single model can suffer more than one hit from each Area Attack. Remember that attacks multiplied into several hits are allocated after establishing how many its are scored (i.e. after the attack has hit).

Figure figure/areaattack illustrates examples of different variations of Area Attack.

Examples of Area Attacks. Units A to D are hit by an Area Attack (33) from an attacker Located in their Front Arc.\ A: There are 3 ranks with more than 3 models. Number of hits: 3 + 3 + 3 = 9.\ B: The first rank has more than 3 models, but the second rank only has 2 models. There is no third rank. Number of hits: 3 + 2 = 5.\ C: Since there is only a single model, there will always only be a single rank with a single model. Number of hits: 1.\ D: The first and second rank have 3 models. There is no third rank. Number of hits: 3 + 3 = 6.\ Units E and F are hit by an Area Attack (14).\ E: The attacker Located in its Front Arc. The first and second rank have more than 1 model. There is no third or fourth rank. Number of hits: 1 + 1 = 2.\ F: The attacker Located in its Flank Arc. There are more than 4 files with 1 or more models. Number of hits: 1 + 1 +1 +1 = 4.

rulebook-crush_attack.title: Crush Attack
rulebook-crush_attack.def: When the model part allocates Attacks, it may choose to exchange all of its Standard Melee Attacks for a single Standard Melee Attack, which has its Str set to 10, its AP set to 10, and gains Multiple Wounds(D3). This cannot be done as a Restricted Attack.

rulebook-devastating_charge.title: Devastating Charge
rulebook-devastating_charge.def: Charging model parts with Devastating Charge, or using a weapon with Devastating Charge, gains the rules and Characteristic modifiers stated in brackets. For example, a model part with Devastating Charge(+1 Str) gains +1 Str when Charging.

rulebook-divine_attacks.title: Divine Attacks
rulebook-divine_attacks.def: Aegis Saves cannot be taken against Divine Attacks.

rulebook-disciplined.title: Disciplined
rulebook-disciplined.def: Command Tests taken by a unit containing Disciplined gain Maximised. Note that this rule interacts with Commanding Presence, see Commanding Presence for details.

rulebook-extra_support.title: Extra Support
rulebook-extra_support.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part replaces the limit on the maximum number of <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> that can be done as Restricted <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> with the value in brackets (X), or if it includes a +, increases the limit with +X.

rulebook-fight_in_extra_rank.title: Fight in Extra Rank
rulebook-fight_in_extra_rank.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> parts with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fight_in_extra_rank">Fight in Extra Rank</nuxt-link>, or using a weapon with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fight_in_extra_rank">Fight in Extra Rank</nuxt-link>, can make Supporting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> from an additional rank.

rulebook-flaming_attacks.title: Flaming Attacks
rulebook-flaming_attacks.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/regeneration">Regeneration</nuxt-link> <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/saves">Saves</nuxt-link> cannot be taken against <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/flaming_attacks">Flaming Attacks</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-lightning_attacks.title: Lightning Attacks
rulebook-lightning_attacks.def: Lightning Attacks must reroll failed to-wound rolls against models without Metal Armour.

rulebook-fury.title: Fury
rulebook-fury.def: If the attack hits with a natural to-hit roll of ‘6’, the attack causes one additional hit usually this means it causes two hits instead of one. This additional hit is Allocated towards the same target.

rulebook-hatred.title: Hatred
rulebook-hatred.def: An attack with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hatred">Hatred</nuxt-link> must reroll failed to-hit rolls.

rulebook-handandahalf.title: Hand-and-a-Half
rulebook-handandahalf.def: The model part ignores Two-Handed, and its weapons count as a Hand Weapon for the purpose of Shield (while keeping other rules and modifiers).

rulebook-lethal_strike.title: Lethal Strike
rulebook-lethal_strike.def: An attack with Lethal Strike that wounds with a natural to-wound roll of ‘6’, has its AP always set to 10, and Regeneration Saves cannot be taken against it.

rulebook-magical_attacks.title: Magical Attacks
rulebook-magical_attacks.def: This Attack Attribute doesn’t confer any direct effects, but instead interacts with other rules, such as Aegis (X, against Magical Attacks).

rulebook-march_and_shoot.title: March and Shoot
rulebook-march_and_shoot.def: Performing a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_move">March Move</nuxt-link> in the same Player Turn does not prevent shooting with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">attacks</nuxt-link> or <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> parts with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_and_shoot">March and Shoot</nuxt-link>, but the attack can still suffer -1 to hit for Moving and Shooting.

rulebook-multiple_wounds.title: Multiple Wounds
rulebook-multiple_wounds.def:
Unsaved wounds caused by the attack are multiplied into the value given in brackets (X). If the value is a dice, roll one dice for each unsaved wound from an attack with Multiple Wounds. The amount of wounds that the attack is multiplied into can never be higher than the Health Points Characteristic of the target, excluding Health Points lost previously in the battle.

For example, if a Multiple Wounds(D6) attack wounds a unit of Trolls (HP 3) and rolls a ‘5’ for the multiplier, the number of unsaved wounds is reduced to 3, even if the Troll unit has already lost one or two Health Points previously in battle.

rulebook-poison_attacks.title: Poison Attacks
rulebook-poison_attacks.def:
If the attack hits with a natural to-hit roll of ‘6’, it automatically wounds (no to-wound roll needed). If the attack has two or more instances of Poison Attacks, and it hits with a successful natural to-hit roll of ‘5’ or ‘6’ it automatically wounds.

If the attack is turned into more than one hit (e.g. a hit with Area Attack or Fury), only a single hit, chosen by the attacker, automatically wounds. All other hits must roll to wound as normal.

rulebook-quick_to_fire.title: Quick to Fire
rulebook-quick_to_fire.def: The Attack does not suffer the -1 to-hit modifier for Moving and Shooting.

rulebook-rage.title: Rage
rulebook-rage.def: Whenever the model loses a Health Point, it gains +1 Attack Value. Whenever it Recovers or Raises a Health Point, it suffers -1 Attack Value.

rulebook-shoot_in_extra_rank.title: Shoot in Extra Rank
rulebook-shoot_in_extra_rank.def: The model part may use Shooting Attacks from one additional rank. Normally, this means that model parts with Shoot in Extra Rank, will be able to make Shooting Attacks from the third rank.

rulebook-toxic_attacks.title: Toxic Attacks
rulebook-toxic_attacks.def: The attack has its Strength always set to 3 and its Armour Penetration always set to 10.

rulebook-twohanded.title: Two-Handed
rulebook-twohanded.def: A model using a Two-Handed Melee Weapon can not simultaneously use a Shield against Melee Attacks.

rulebook-unwieldy.title: Unwieldy
rulebook-unwieldy.def: If the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> performed a Move Manoeuvre in the current Player Turn, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/unwieldy">Unwieldy</nuxt-link> suffer -X to Hit. This modifier can be combined with the -1 to-hit modifier from shooting in the same turn as performing a  Move Manoeuvre.

rulebook-weapon_master.title: Weapon Master
rulebook-weapon_master.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part may choose what Melee Weapon to use in each Round of Combat, instead of only in the first. The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part may also choose to use a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hand_weapon">Hand Weapon</nuxt-link>, or Innate <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/weapons">Weapons</nuxt-link> even if it has another Melee Weapon. If armed with an Enchanted Weapon, the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part must still use it, and all Rank-and-File <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">models</nuxt-link> still need to choose the same. I. e. the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part only need to follow priority step 1 and 2 of weapon choices.

rulebook-zeal.title: Zeal
rulebook-zeal.def: An attack with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/zeal">Zeal</nuxt-link> must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-elven_finesse.title: Elven Finesse
rulebook-elven_finesse.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> parts with this Attack Attribute Attacking with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/great_weapon">Great Weapons</nuxt-link> strike at -1 Agility instead of always at Agility 0.

rulebook-first_strike.title: First Strike
rulebook-first_strike.def: During the First Round of Combat, model parts with First Strike, or using a weapon with First Strike, gains the rules and Characteristic modifiers stated in brackets. For example, a model part with First Strike(+1 Str) gains +1 Str in the first round of combat.

rulebook-direct_hit.title: Direct Hit
rulebook-direct_hit.def:
When the attack hits, after determining the number of hits (e.g. using Area Attack), one of the hits, chosen by the attacker, gains the rules and Characteristic modifiers stated in brackets. If Str or AP is given directly, set the Str or AP to that value. For example, Direct Hit (Str 10, AP 6) means one hit has its Str set to 10 and its AP set to 6
.

rulebook-horror.title: Horror
rulebook-horror.def:
Flee Moves from enemy units made in the following situations gain Minimised two times:


  • Flee! Charge Reactions declared in reaction to a Charge Declaration from a unit containing this rule. (Flee! Charge Reactions declared when later charged by other units are unaffected.)

  • Breaking from combat while in contact with one or more units containing Horror.



Remember that units containing Fearless are unaffected by this rule.

rulebook-breath_attack.title: Breath Attack
rulebook-breath_attack.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_and_shoot">March and Shoot</nuxt-link>. Hits automatically (no to-hit roll required). The Strength, Armour Penetration, and additional <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attack_attributes">Attack Attributes</nuxt-link> are defined in brackets (X).

rulebook-grind_attack.title: Grind Attack
rulebook-grind_attack.def:
The model part can make a Special Attack which is resolved with the model part’s Agility, and inflicts X hits, using the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration, and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.
Remember that attacks multiplied into several hits are allocated after establishing how many hits are scored (i.e. after the attack has hit).

rulebook-impact_hits.title: Impact Hits
rulebook-impact_hits.def:
If Charging, the model part can make a Special Attack which is resolved at Agility Step 10, and inflicts X hits, using the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration, and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.
Remember that attacks multiplied into several hits are allocated after establishing how many hits are scored (i.e. after the attack has hit).

If more than one model part of a combined model has Impact Hits, only a single Model Part can perform its Impact Hits in each Round of Combat (owner’s choice).

rulebook-sweeping_attack.title: Sweeping Attack
rulebook-sweeping_attack.def:
When a model with Sweeping Attack is within 1" of an unengaged enemy unit during a Move Manoeuvre (even temporarily), the model’s unit may perform a Sweeping Attack against that enemy unit. This can only be used once per friendly Player Turn. Resolve the Sweeping Attack when the Move Manoeuvre is completed.

The attack hits automatically, and counts as a Ranged Attack. Each model in the unit with Sweeping Attack must use its Sweeping Attack against the same enemy unit. The Sweeping Attack hits automatically, causing a number of hits as defined in the brackets (X hits). These hits are resolved with the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.

If values for Strength, Armour Penetration and additional Attack Attributes are defined in the bracket (Y), these are used instead. In this case, note that characteristics modifiers and Attack Attributes on the model part itself do not affect this attack.

rulebook-standard_melee_attacks.title: Standard Melee Attacks
rulebook-standard_melee_attacks.def:
Standard Melee Attacks

The most common type of attack in the Melee Phase is the Standard Melee Attack, which all models can perform provided they have an Attack Value on their profile (see Characteristic Profiles in the Definitions and Terminology chapter). To resolve these attacks, roll a number of D6 equal to the Attack Value of the attacking model part. This roll is called a to-hit roll.

Compare the attacking model part's Offensive Skill with the target model's Defensive Skill and consult the table below for the needed dice roll to score a successful hit. A natural roll of ‘1’ is always a failure, and a natural roll of ‘6’ is always a success. Both tables present the same relation, visualised in different ways.

Offensive Skill -
Defensive Skill		 Needed roll to hit
4 or more 2+
1 to 3 3+
-3 to 0 4+
-4 or less 5+


Once you have determined the number of hits, follow the Attack Sequence, using the Strength, Armour Penetration, and on the profile of the attacking model part, potentially modified by things like Weapon, Spells and Model Rules.

Non-Standard Melee Attacks

Attacks that do not fall under the category of Standard Melee Attacks, have their own specific rules for determining the number of hits, as well as the Strength, Armour Penetration, and additional rules to use.

Off 1 Off 2 Off 3 Off 4 Off 5 Off 6 Off 7 Off 8 Off 9 Off 10
Def 1 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Def 2 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Def 3 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Def 4 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+ 2+ 2+
Def 5 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+ 2+
Def 6 5+ 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+ 2+
Def 7 5+ 5+ 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+ 3+
Def 8 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+ 3+
Def 9 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 3+
Def 10 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 5+ 4+ 4+ 4+ 4+

rulebook-standard_bearer.title: Standard Bearer
rulebook-standard_bearer.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/standard_bearer">Standard Bearer</nuxt-link> is a unit-wide upgrade, normally represented by the presence of a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> carrying the unit standard, icon, military insignia, totem, or other similar symbol. A unit containing a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/standard_bearer">Standard Bearer</nuxt-link> adds +1 to the Combat Score of its side.

rulebook-musician.title: Musician
rulebook-musician.def: Musician is a unit-wide upgrade, normally represented by the presence of a regimental musician. Command Tests taken by units containing Musician gain Maximised.

rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.title: Duplicate Model Rules
rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.def: Most Model Rules are not cumulative. This means that if a model gains the same rule multiple times, the effects don’t stack or provide extra benefits. This includes Model Rules with different keywords attached (such as Multiple Wounds(against Height 2) and Multiple Wounds(against Height 3)), which are considered to be the same Model Rule and thus both instances cannot be applied simultaneously. In such cases, the owner may choose which instance of the Model Rule to use at any point in time.

rulebook-model_rules_and_units.title: Model Rules and Units
rulebook-model_rules_and_units.def:
Even though Model Rules are given to individual models, there are some Model Rules that function on unit level, such as dictating how entire units can move or operate. Model Rules differentiate between the following cases:


  • Units with X: Whenever a Model Rule or Property is referred to as units with the rule, this means units where every single model in it has Rule X or Property X.

  • Units containing X: Whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units containing the rule, this means units where at least one model in it has Rule X or Property X.

  • Units not containing X: Whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units not containing the rule, this means units where no single model in it has Rule X or Property X.

rulebook-attack_attributes.title: Attack Attributes
rulebook-attack_attributes.def:
Attack attributes is a subcategory of Model Rules. While most Model Rules apply to the entire model, including all model parts on the same base, Attack Attributes are the exception, and only affect individual model parts, or even individual attacks. Attack Attributes by default only affect Melee Attacks.
Attack Attributes for models are therefore written under the Offensive Characteristics part of the model entry, and thus only affect the specific model part it’s listed under. Note however that if an Attack Attribute is given to a unit (e.g. as a result of a spell), it applies to every model part in that unit, and if given to a model, it applies to all parts of that model.
In addition to being given to a model part, Attack Attributes can also be given to a weapon, a spell, or an attack. Such Attack Attributes only affect attacks made with those specific sources. They won’t affect other attacks made by the same model part.
Attack Attributes by default only affect Melee Attacks. There are two main exceptions to this:


  • An Attack Attribute given specifically to a weapon, a spell or attack will affect it regardless of if it would normally only be applicable to Melee Attacks.

  • Attack Attributes that come with their own Strength, Armour Penetration (including Attack Attributes that et the Str/AP of the attack, such as Toxic Attacks) are not affected by Attack Attributes on the model part. For example, a dragon might have Grind Attack(Str, AP, Flaming Attacks) and Lethal Strike. The hits from its Grind Attack are not affected by Lethal Strike, since this is an Attribute on the dragon itself.

rulebook-weapons.title: Weapons
rulebook-weapons.def:
Weapons is a subcategory of Model Rules. Similarly with Attack Attributes, Weapons can only be used by the model part that has the rule. Model parts with Mount, Beast, or Construct cannot use Weapons other than Innate Weapons, unless specifically stated otherwise (e.g. a Beast Model Part with a Weapon directly on its Profile can use this Weapon).

There are two types of weapons:


  • Melee Weapon: A model part can only use a single Melee Weapon simultaneously, and only when Engaged in combat. If the model is equipped with multiple Melee Weapons, choose which one to use in the first Round of Combat, in this priority order:


  • An enchanted weapon

  • Any weapon that is neither a Hand Weapon, nor Innate Weapons

  • A Hand Weapon

  • Innate Weapons


This choice is then kept until the model is no longer Engaged in Combat. Melee Weapons are used with the model part’s Standard Melee Attacks.



  • Modifiers to Offensive Characteristics and Attack Attributes are applied only to the model part’s Standard Melee Attacks.

  • Modifiers to Global or Defensive Characteristics (Mob, Cha, Cou, Def, HP, Res, or Arm), and Model Rules that are not Attack Attributes, are applied to the model or model part (see rules for Character Mounts for details when and how Characteristics of mounts are affected) at all times except while using a different Melee Weapon.

  • Variable bonuses, such as those based on a dice roll, are determined at the start of the Agility Step in which the weapon is used.




  • Shooting Weapon: Shooting Weapons are used for making Shooting Attacks. Each model part can only use one Shooting Weapon per phase. A Shooting Weapon typically has an Aim Value, shown in brackets after the name of the weapon. The rules for the Shooting Weapon will define the weapon’s maximum Range, the number of Shots fired, and the Strength, Armour Penetration, and potentially Attack Attributes applied to its attacks.

rulebook-keywords.title: Keywords
rulebook-keywords.def:
Model Rules include keywords to help define their effects. These keywords can be used directly within the rulebook, which applies to rules that always have that keyword. Alternatively, keywords can be specified for individual rules on specific models, spells, or weapons. In this case this is done within brackets following the name of the rule.

Below follows a list of Model Rule keywords:


  • Shooting or Melee & Shooting (Attack Attributes only): An Attack Attribute with the keyword Shooting only affects attacks made with Shooting Weapons, while an Attack Attribute with the keyword Melee & Shooting affects both Melee Attacks and attacks made with Shooting Weapons.


  • Remember that the default if none of these keywords are used is that Attack Attributes only affect Melee Attacks.

  • For example, by default Poison Attacks affect only Melee Attacks. If a model part has Poison Attacks(Shooting), this means the Poison Attacks rule applies only to attacks made with that model part’s Shooting Weapons, unless it also has Poison Attacks or Poison Attacks(Melee & Shooting).



  • Special Attacks: Apply the following rules to Attack Attributes with this keyword. A model with this rule can make a special Melee Attack (which is not a Standard Melee Attack), that hits automatically. Since not a Standard Melee Attack this attack can usually not be made as a Supporting Attack and does not suffer from Restricted Attacks (see Melee chapter). Special Attacks cannot be allocated towards Attachable Models that could not be the target of a Ranged Attack (see Attacks chapter).

  • Cumulative: Effects from multiple instances of a Model Rule with the Cumulative keyword are combined and add up.

  • Distance Modifiers: Denoted as a number followed by ". Any distances in the Model Rule description is replaced by the number. For example, Vanguard (3"") means that the model can perform a Vanguard move, but its Mobility is set to 3" instead of the normal 6".

  • Towards X: The Attack Attribute only applies if the attack is allocated to a specific type of enemy model. The conditions are given as X. If more than one type of enemy is relevant they are separated by or. If multiple conditions must be fulfilled, these conditions are separated by and. For example, Multiple Wounds(2, towards Height 4 and Beast, or Height 5) means that Multiple Wounds can be used versus models that are both Height 4 and Beast, as well as versus models that are Height 5, regardless of if the model has the Beast Property or not.

  • Against X: The Model Rule only applies when attacked by a certain type of model or with certain Rules or Properties. See the rules under Towards X for how to interpret or and and. For example, Hard Target(against Lethal Strike) means that the model can only use its Hard Target rule when attacked by an attack with Lethal Strike.

  • Unique Keywords: In addition to the standard model rule keywords defined above, certain Model Rules have unique keywords. These are defined in the respective rules themselves.

rulebook-introduction.def:
Welcome to the tabletop wargame known as The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, or T9A for short. This is a community crafted miniatures wargame, where grand armies collide in monumental conflicts for supremacy and survival. The game is played on a tabletop with terrain features and miniatures to represent the battlefield and the clashing armies, and it uses six-sided dice and measuring devices to move miniatures and resolve actions such as charging into battle, letting arrows loose, and casting spells.

For all the rules, feedback, and suggestions, please visit our webpage: the-ninth-age.com. The rules presented in this book are considered the Core Rules of T9A and are used in all T9A games. \
Licence: Copyright Creative Commons

Rules representation

In order to keep rules clear and tidy, the following text formatting is used:

Text in a grey box denotes designer notes. In these are the designers giving some insights into intent behind rules, alternate ways to play the game, or shortcuts to speed things up.

  • Capitalization is used for words/phrases that are defined in this book, such as Round of Combat, unless they are common words with no elaborate game definition like model or unit, but Combat is since it is not used like the common British term.

  • Bold font or text is used to highlight specific words. It is also used in Army Books to emphasise Model Rules specified in the same unit entry.

  • Italic font marks reminders, examples, clarifications, and other content that are not direct rules.

  • Grey-coloured text is used for figure and table captions, item restrictions, repetitive content, and Properties, which is a special type of keyword that doesn’t transfer any direct rules.

  • Hyperlinks can be found in the electronic version of this document, and the page footer includes hyperlinks to key sections.

  • Pink text is unique to the Reference Handbook . This Handbook covers corner-cases and specific circumstances that are not expected to be relevant in the majority of games. The Handbook is a copy of the Illustrated Rulebook with additional sections added to cover these corner-cases.

Rules Documents

Illustrated Rulebook

The Illustrated Rulebook contains a streamlined version of the main rules needed for playing the game, alongside art, miniature images and lore.
Appendices

Appendices are an integral component of the core rules, and are generally used in most games. There are two appendices to the Illustrated Rulebook:

  • Illustrated Rulebook - Appendix I: Model Rules -- Additional and unique rules that specific models possess.

  • Illustrated Rulebook - Appendix II: Arcane Compendium -- The compendium contains spells from the ten different paths of magic, along with the common Magic Items.

  •

  •

  •

  •

Season Packs

These documents comprise additional deployment types, maps, and secondary objectives, catering towards more advanced games.

Reference Handbook

This handbook includes all rules from the Illustrated Rulebook, plus Appendix I: Model Rules and Appendix II: Arcane Compendium documents. Additionally, it includes extended rules text to cover for intricate and complex battlefield situations. We recommend that players who prefer to understand complex situations in advance and fully grasp the nuances of all rule interactions, to turn directly to this document.

For new players and those who prefer to deal with intricate scenarios as they arise, we suggest starting with the Illustrated Rulebook and only referring to the Reference Handbook when specific situations occur that are not fully covered in the Illustrated Rulebook.

This document is the Illustrated Rulebook, containing a streamlined version of the main rules needed for playing the game alongside art, miniature images and lore. In addition to this, you will need a few more documents to play a full game of T9A.\
Army Books

The rules for the different armies are found in Army Books. Within these, you will find army composition rules, unit and model rules, characteristics, and so on.

Supplements

Supplements are optional add-ons to the game that require an agreement with the opponent before using.
rulebook-introduction.title: Introduction

rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.def:
This game is divided into three main sections, performed in order.

1 - Battle Preparations. Before a game, certain preparations are needed. The players need to put together their armies, prepare the Battlefield, select victory conditions and deploy their armies onto the Battlefield.

2 - Game Turns. This is a turn-based game, with standard games comprising six Game Turns. Each Game Turn is further divided into two Player Turns, wherein each player takes turns controlling their respective armies in a series of Phases which are performed in the following sequence:

  • Charge Phase

  • Movement Phase

  • Magic Phase

  • Shooting Phase

  • Rally Phase

  • Melee Phase

3 - After the Game. After both players have played six Player Turns, it is time to tally up the Victory Points and check who managed to win the Primary and Secondary Objectives to see who is the winner of the Game.


Greeeetings! I am Klepa, one hundred percent honest and reliable merchant goblin. This is my healthful and fine-smelling accomplice – ah – pet! my charming pet: Fleabag. For smallest of prices, and promise not to talk to mean old city guards, we can be your guides here. Klepa will share all his, er, lawfully ack-quee-zis-shined knowledge about the wide world of the Ninth Age! Such a pleasure to meet a new mark – I mean customer! Customer and friend! Welcome

Active & Reactive Player


The Active Player is the one currently taking their Player Turn, and the Reactive Player is the one whose Player Turn is not currently happening.

Friendly and Enemy

The terms friendly and enemy are used to distinguish between units that belong to the same player (friendly units) and units controlled by opposing players (enemy units).

Your First Game


Is this your first game? Let’s get you started. First, prepare your battlefield: a large flat surface with model terrain on – a pile of books can be a hill, a mug can be a rock, a mouse pad can be a lake, and so on. Then, challenge a friend to a game where you both command your own miniature army.

For a trial run without the commitment of time and resources, we offer downloadable paper cutouts on the T9A website (address provided at the beginning of this book).

If you're uncertain about which army to choose, a brief overview of the 16 main armies and their primary themes can be found in the Introduction chapter.


If you're uncertain about which army to choose, a brief overview of the 16 main armies and their primary themes can be found in the Introduction chapter.
rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.title: The Flow of the Game

rulebook-battle_preparations.def:
Before battle can be joined, you must establish the nature of the battlefield, the armies that will fight upon it, and their reason for being there. This is a natural part of setting up the game, but it can also represent a commander reviewing their troops and scouting the land in preparation for an important battle.


When preparing to play a game of The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, players follow a series of steps:

1 - Pregame planning (typically done before players arrive to the gaming table)

  • Army Size is decided, which determines the size of the game. This can be done by the players agreeing on an Army Size, or an outside source such as campaign rules or a tournament organiser dictating this.

  • Build an Army. Each player creates an Army Lists from one of the Armybooks.

2 - Initial preparations (these are sometimes done before arrival - typical in a tournament setting, and sometimes done by both players together - typical in more casual settings)

  • Build the Battlefield by setting up terrain and scenery to create an engaging and challenging environment for the battle.

  • Share Army Lists with your opponent, revealing the units and options you will be using during the game.

  • Select Victory Conditions. Normally this means picking Primary and Secondary Objectives, which define the goals for the coming battle.

  • Select Deployment Type. This defines how the armies will be placed on the Battlefield before the game begins.


3 - Battle setup (these actions are done at the gaming table by both players together)

  • Roll-off for Attacker and Defender. The players roll-off to see who will decide, which player is going to be the Defender, the other will be the Attacker.

  • Defender Decides Deployment Zones. These are the areas where each player's army will start the game.

  • Pregame Selections. Choices to make before deployment are made at this step. Common choices include choices for Secondary Objectives and Spell Swaps.

  • Deploy units. Players place their units, starting with the Attacker, within their designated deployment zones.

  • Move Vanguarding units. Units with the model rule Vanguard perform their pre-game movement.


Season Packs are an annually updated supplement that can provide support in building a battlefield and add several variations on deployment types, Primary Objectives and Secondary Objectives. If you are looking for a fast and simple game, or this is one of your first games, we recommend you use the rules below and leave Season Packs for next time.

/section{pregame_planning}/section{initial_preparations}/section{battle_setup}
rulebook-battle_preparations.title: Battle Preparations

rulebook-army_size.def:
Before building an army, players need to agree on the size of the battle, which is referred to as Army Size. The combined point costs of all the units in the army should not exceed the designated Army Size, and it is allowed to be not more than max 50 points below the limit.

The rules for army composition are modified depending on the size of an army.

Point Cost


Point Cost, often shortened pts, is a measure of the power of a unit or upgrade. We use pts to ensure that two armies with a similar total Points Cost facing each other is a fair balanced game.

All units have an associated Points Cost, which is determined by adding its starting Point Cost of additional models added to the unit, and Points Cost of the additional options the unit selects.
rulebook-army_size.title: Army Size

rulebook-build_an_army.def:
As the player, it is your duty to command your army on the battlefield, but first you will have to pick one of the different factions available to you. Each Army Book contains a description of the different units that are available to its faction, as well as their characteristics and special rules that apply to them.

To start building your army, you create an Army List, which includes the selection of units, spells and options you want to use along with their point costs. Every unit, weapon, upgrade, and Magic Item has a specific point cost, which is used to balance the game and ensure fair play between players.

Planning, strategy, knowing terrain, learning about the ponent – very useful for a heist! What? You were asking about battles? Oh yes, Klepa knows them too. We goblins are Warborn after all – that’s the name us and orc pals call ourselves together. Klepa has seen all the great battles, seen loads of action! Normally from quite far away – so you know I had a good view.
Main thing I’ve learned is you’ve got to get there early if you want the best spot for hiding and picking over the loot at the end. You want some loot? Genuine, authentikarated battle gear, picked from the choiciest corpses! Just step quietly over to Appendicitis Numero Two and we’ll have a little chat about the low low prices.


Army Books

The rules for playing the various factions are detailed in Army Books and supplement Army Books (remember that using a supplement requires the agreement of your opponent or event organiser).

Unit Entries

Each entry in an Army Book is categorised into different Army Categories, each represented by specific icons in the unit entries of the Army Book.
